Award.AwardTitle: CHS: Small: How recommendation and explanation affect preferences in social networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to advance research on a novel perspective on recommendation called network-centric recommender systems. Sharing information with others is a key driver of social media activity. But, surprisingly, relatively little is known about how people make choices around what to share and to read, or whom to share with and pay attention to. Unlike traditional e-commerce and research contexts that focus on accurate prediction for individuals at a given moment, the network-centric perspective sees recommendation as a dynamic social process. Understanding more about the factors that influence recommendation processes will have practical impact on the design of social media platforms and recommender systems, leading to tools that better serve both individual and societal goals around sharing information. It will also set the stage for an understanding of how information spreads in social networks that is deeper than current diffusion models that fail to account for these factors, allowing scientists to build more accurate and more general models of sharing behavior.

A series of laboratory experiments will ask people to make and take recommendations from each other. These experiments will use real social media data such as Facebook Likes and Twitter hashtag usage, but control the algorithms, interfaces, and partners people interact with in the experiment. Doing this will help weigh the importance of factors that influence people's sharing and reading behavior. Among these factors are how users are influenced by goals such as self-expression and helping people, system characteristics such as filtering algorithms and social explanations for shared items, and social forces such as similarity and trust between a sharer and a receiver.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Recommending and sharing information with others is a key driver of social activity online but also in face-to-face interaction. Surprisingly, relatively little is known about how people make choices around what to share and to read, or whom to share with and pay attention to. The high level goal of this project was to investigate connections between recommendations, preferences, and information diffusion in networks.  This includes studying micro-level interactions where people might influence each other's decisions, either directly through making recommendations, or indirectly through social information being used in explanations.  It also includes modeling how this influence, moderated by people's own preferences for items, affects the way items spread through a network.

Based on our studies we developed an analytic framework for predicting how items become popular in social networks based on early activity around the items. We developed novel tools that make it easier for people to access shared information. For example, we developed a search engine for Reddit forums that would help people find forums that were not just topical matches for information they wanted to share but that would also have 'the right' audiences in terms of the kinds of responses and attention people might be seeking. Finally, we explored how sharing of information is affected in interactions that involve physically embodied systems such as a robot. We learned that people share more resources when treated unequally by a robot and that being treated unfairly by a robot leads to changes in peoples? perceptions about their own contribution. 

Intellectual merit: The project contributed to the fields of computer mediated communication and computer-supported cooperative work by developing new theories and understandings of the role that technology plays in shaping how people communicate and collaborate. It contributed to human-computer interaction and related fields through the development of new techniques and tools for enhancing communication and collaboration. It also contributed to the fields of psychology, communication, and organizational behavior by increasing our knowledge of team dynamics.

Broader impacts: The grant provided training for several doctoral students, and one postdoc, several of which have since accepted positions in industry and academia. It also provided training for many undergraduate and Master's students. The tools we developed were demonstrated at science fairs for high school students and for the general public, in undergraduate courses, and at leading conferences. The work led to several publications in top journals and conference proceedings, and our findings were presented at major conferences and in invited addresses at top academic institutions and companies. All tools we developed have been made freely available to the public.
